prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: In the Nova Scotia Supreme Court decision of Hawboldt Industries Ltd v. Chester Basin Hydraulics & Machine Ltd.,[1] the court stated that fiduciaries are prevented from directly soliciting, for a reasonable time, any customer of the employer that was a customer during the employee's tenure:

Employees are free to compete with their former employer, but they are precluded from competing by soliciting persons or firms who were customers of the employer while the employee was employed by the employer. They are also precluded from doing so for a reasonable time afterwards. They are precluded from direct solicitation.
[Emphasis added.]
Other cases, such as the decision in Sure-Grip Fasteners,[2] have also confirmed that a fiduciary will only be restrained for a reasonable time:

An employee who is a fiduciary is precluded from competing with the employer by means of direct solicitation of the employer's customers, for a reasonable period of time after termination of the employment.
Similarly, in Sulphur Experts Inc. v. O'Connell, the court concluded that:

Even if fiduciary duties of non-competition and non-solicitation exist, they only exist for a reasonable period of time after termination of employment. What is reasonable period often depends on the standard of loyalty and good faith imposed on an employee, which depends on the circumstances of the employment relationship. Courts in similar cases have held that a year is appropriate: Sun Drilling Products Corp. v. Garrett (1999), 245 A.R. 370 (Q.B.).[3]

The length of time that fiduciary obligations may extend beyond the termination of the relationship will be governed by the particular circumstances. In Benayoune & Associates FZE v. Kanata Chemical Technologies Inc.,[4] in the course of the KCT receivership, certain assets, including intellectual property, were conveyed to the moving party Kanata. Choses in action were also assigned to Kanata. Kanata brought a motion for an interlocutory injunction against Kamal and Muhammad, former senior executives of KCT, and their new company, Kamal, a competing business. The respondents were brothers. Both were directors of KCT. Because of the receivership, Kamal and Muhammad were notified that their employment was terminated. However, both of them were given an offer to continue to assist the Receiver on a temporary basis. Muhammad did so until August 27, 2013. Kamal did so until October 7, 2013. Both Kamal and Muhammad were left with substantial unpaid employee remuneration after the receivership. Benayoune put together a bid on KCT's assets and entered into an agreement with the Receiver through a company that became Kanata. An Asset Purchase Agreement was approved by the court and the asset sale closed on October 18, 2013. Kanata then initiated its business with a view to marketing the same proprietary technologies previously sold by KCT. On September 26, 2013, Kamal and Muhammad each tendered their resignation as KCT directors and registered a URL for a new website. A new company was incorporated shortly thereafter.[5]

Injunctive relief was sought on the basis that the Agreements with Kamal and Muhammad were effectively assigned to Kanata under the APA, and that KCT's cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty by Kamal and Muhammad was effectively assigned by the Receiver as provided for in the APA. The motions judge concluded that Kanata must show a strong prima facie case. The motions judge observed that judicial consensus has imposed the requirement of a strong prima facie case in cases that involved restrictive covenants and employment contracts, and in actions against former employees. The strong prima facie case threshold means that the moving party must show that the claim is almost certain to succeed.[6]

The motions judge also observed that Kamal and Muhammad obviously owed fiduciary duties to KCT. They were both directors and very senior officers. However, the business of KCT came to an end when it was assigned into bankruptcy by the Receiver in October 2013. As of that time, all or substantially all of its assets had been sold. Kamal and Muhammad had resigned as directors and their employment had been terminated. Nonetheless, their fiduciary duties to KCT may have continued to some degree.[7]

Kanata submitted that Kamal and Muhammad should have told the Receiver of their plans to set up a competing business, and if they had done so the transaction captured in the APA would have “cratered”. If so, the motions judge noted there might be a remedy. However, the issue on the motion was the availability of an interlocutory injunction now, as opposed to at that time, rather than a claim for damages. Whatever might have happened at the time, it remained the case that shortly thereafter the APA closed, KCT was assigned into bankruptcy and it had ceased all business. The opportunity for KCT to negotiate a different deal could not be recreated now using the proposed interlocutory injunction.[8]

Kanata also alleged improper solicitation of customers and misuse of confidential information. The proposed injunction regarding customer solicitation may have been relevant to KCT in 2013, but a fiduciary duty regarding non-solicitation ordinarily only continues post-termination in order to give the company time to solidify its relationships with customers before the former employee begins competition. That purpose did not support the continuation of the fiduciary duties to KCT.[9]

Finally, with respect to confidential information, there was the possibility of a direct claim by Kanata for breach of confidence but it had not been pleaded. There was also the possibility of that given the sale of the intellectual property and goodwill, the fiduciary duty to protect confidential information formerly of KCT continued for a reasonable time post-closing and post-bankruptcy. However, the court did not find the requisite strong prima facie case of breach of such a fiduciary duty. There was some evidence, which was flatly denied, and it did not meet the required threshold.[10]

In summary, employers have the right for a period of time to be free from interference by a former fiduciary employee in order to solidify and maintain their existing customer relationships and ensure that no confidential information is used as a tool to take away such business. The size of the market and the nature of the industry will usually be of relevance to the court. However, in some businesses such as the professions the courts have been less willing to conclude that a business has an inherent right to its customers free of solicitation.[11] The stronger the employer's market position, the less likely the courts are to see the employer as vulnerable to the competition of the former employee.

The question often arises as to whether fiduciary duties survive a wrongful dismissal. A number of cases have addressed this issue. In Zesta Engineering Ltd. v. Cloutier, the court considered the decision in General Billposting v. Atkinson[12] at length and offered a good discussion of the need to be both flexible and balanced.[13] In some circumstances, the time restraint on competition has been eliminated where the fiduciary was terminated or constructively dismissed.[14]
